{{Infobox person | name = Brent Hayes Edwards | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | image_upright = | image_size = <!-- DISCOURAGED per WP:IMGSIZE. Use image_upright. --> | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year with {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = | baptised = <!-- will not display if birth_date is entered --> | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[Yale University]] (BA); [[Columbia University]] (MA, PhD) | occupation = Professor | years_active = | era = | employer = Columbia University | notable_works = ''[[The Practice of Diaspora|The Practice of Diaspora: Literature, Translation, and the Rise of Black Internationalism]]'' | style = | home_town = | movement = | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = <!-- may be used (optionally with mother parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | relatives = | family = | awards = [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''Brent Hayes Edwards''' is a professor of English and [[comparative literature]] at [[Columbia University]].
==Early life== Edwards attended [[Yale]] as an undergraduate, then completed an MA and PhD at Columbia.
==Career== ===Teaching=== Edwards has taught at Rutgers University<ref>{{cite news|title=Newsletter of the Friends of Rutgers English: Online - Excellence Recognized|url=http://english.rutgers.edu/alumni/newsletter/fall_winter_03/excellence_recognized.html|accessdate=10 August 2016|work=english.rutgers.edu|issue=Fall/winter|date=2003}}</ref> and now at Columbia, as well as [[Cornell University|Cornell]]'s summer graduate program, the [[School of Criticism and Theory]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Past Faculty {{!}} The School of Criticism and Theory|url=http://sct.cornell.edu/past-faculty/|website=sct.cornell.edu|publisher=Cornell University|accessdate=10 August 2016}}</ref> and the [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] summer graduate program [[The Futures of American Studies]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Futures Faculty: 2006|url=http://www.dartmouth.edu/~futures/faculty/faculty_2006.html|website=www.dartmouth.edu|publisher=Dartmouth college|accessdate=10 August 2016}}</ref>
===Scholarship=== Edwards's first book is ''[[The Practice of Diaspora|The Practice of Diaspora: Literature, Translation, and the Rise of Black Internationalism]]'' ([[Harvard University Press]], 2003). It examines black writers in the [[interwar period]], focusing on sites of interaction between [[Anglophone]] and [[Francophone]] black writers to develop an argument about the generative potential of translation, specifically in the black diaspora.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Stephens|first1=Michelle|title=The Practice of Diaspora: Literature, Translation, and the Rise of Black Internationalism (review)|journal=MFS Modern Fiction Studies|date=Fall 2004|volume=50|issue=3|pages=792–794|doi=10.1353/mfs.2004.0090|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/172395|accessdate=9 August 2016|issn=1080-658X}}</ref> Among other influences, Edwards draws on [[Stuart Hall (cultural theorist)|Stuart Hall]]'s use of the concept of [[Articulation (sociology)|articulation]] to develop a theoretical use of the French term décalage, "referring to a shift in space or time or the gap that results from it...[Edwards argues] that these disparate locations are, like joints, sites of potential forward motion."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Kristina Kay|title=My Journey From Louisiana to Havana, and Back Again|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/my-journey-from-louisiana-to-havana-and-back-again/|accessdate=9 August 2016|work=The Nation|date=July 15, 2016}}</ref>
Edwards also edited the collection ''Uptown Conversation: The New Jazz Studies'' ([[Columbia University Press]], 2004) with [[Farah Griffin|Farah Jasmine Griffin]] and Robert G. O'Meally.
In 2009, Edwards edited a new printing of [[W.E.B. DuBois]]'s ''[[The Souls of Black Folk]]'' from [[Oxford University Press]].
Edwards serves on the editorial boards of [[Callalloo]] and [[Transition (magazine)|Transition]].
===Claude McKay manuscript discovery=== In 2009, Edwards's graduate student [[Jean-Christophe Cloutier]] discovered a manuscript in Columbia's [[Rare book and manuscript library|Rare Book and Manuscript Library]] in the papers of writer [[Samuel Roth]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Driscoll|first1=Molly|title=New manuscript by Harlem Renaissance writer Claude McKay is discovered|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Books/chapter-and-verse/2012/0918/New-manuscript-by-Harlem-Renaissance-writer-Claude-McKay-is-discovered|accessdate=9 August 2016|work=Christian Science Monitor|date=18 September 2012}}</ref> In 2012, Edwards and Cloutier, in consultation with other experts and after examining archival materials and personal correspondence, authenticated the manuscript as a previously unknown 1941 work by [[Claude McKay]], called ''Amiable With Big Teeth: A Novel of the Love Affair Between the Communists and the Poor Black Sheep of Harlem''.<ref name=":1">{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Felicia R.|title=Harlem Renaissance Novel by Claude McKay Is Discovered|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/15/books/harlem-renaissance-novel-by-claude-mckay-is-discovered.html?_r=0|accessdate=9 August 2016|work=The New York Times|date=14 September 2012}}</ref> [[Henry Louis Gates]], who served as one of the experts evaluating the manuscript's authenticity, called it a "major discovery...It dramatically expands the canon of novels written by [[Harlem Renaissance]] writers."<ref name=":1" />
===Awards===
In 2004, Edwards's book ''The Practice of Diaspora'' won the [[John Hope Franklin Prize]] from the [[American Studies Association]]<ref>{{cite web|title=ASA Awards and Prizes {{!}} American Studies Association|url=http://www.theasa.net/prizes_and_grants/awards_and_prizes/|website=www.theasa.net|publisher=American Studies Association|accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref> and the Gilbert Chinard Prize of the [[Society for French Historical Studies]], and an honorable mention for the James Russell Lowell Prize of the [[Modern Language Association]].<ref>{{cite web|title=James Russell Lowell Prize Winners {{!}} Modern Language Association|url=https://www.mla.org/Resources/Career/MLA-Honors-and-Awards/Winners-of-MLA-Prizes/Annual-Prize-and-Award-Winners/James-Russell-Lowell-Prize-Winners|website=www.mla.org|publisher=Modern Language Association|accessdate=9 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123192550/https://www.mla.org/Resources/Career/MLA-Honors-and-Awards/Winners-of-MLA-Prizes/Annual-Prize-and-Award-Winners/James-Russell-Lowell-Prize-Winners#|archive-date=2015-11-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In 2005, Edwards won the [[New York Public Library]]'s Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Fellowship,<ref>{{cite web|title=The New York Public Library's Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers Announces 2016-2017 Fellows|url=https://www.nypl.org/press/press-release/april-11-2016/new-york-public-librarys-dorothy-and-lewis-b-cullman-center|website=The New York Public Library|accessdate=10 August 2016}}</ref> to spend one year researching a project on [[jazz]] in New York in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=MacMillan|first1=Sarah|title=Friends of Rutgers - A Newsletter for Alumni and Friends of the Department of English|url=http://english.rutgers.edu/alumni/newsletter/spring_summer_05/bedwards.html|accessdate=10 August 2016|work=english.rutgers.edu|issue=Spring/Summer|date=2005}}</ref>
In 2015, Edwards was awarded a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]]<ref>{{cite web|title=John Simon Guggenheim Foundation {{!}} Brent Hayes Edwards|url=http://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/brent-hayes-edwards/|website=www.gf.org|publisher=Guggenheim Foundation|accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref> to pursue a book project entitled "The Art of the Lecture."<ref>{{cite news|title=Guggenheim Fellowships awarded to three faculty, 16 alumni|url=http://news.yale.edu/2015/04/14/guggenheim-fellowships-awarded-three-faculty-16-alumni|accessdate=9 August 2016|work=Yale News|date=April 14, 2015}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://english.columbia.edu/people/profile/381 Brent Hayes Edwards] at Columbia University
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

The '''Civil Defence Act 1948''' was an [[Act of Parliament|Act]] of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] setting out legislation for [[civil defence]] procedures in the [[United Kingdom]]. It was repealed and replaced by the [[Civil Contingencies Act 2004]].
== See also == * [[Civil Defence Act (Northern Ireland) 1950]]

The '''conte cruel''' is, as ''The A to Z of Fantasy Literature'' by [[Brian Stableford]] states, a "short-story genre that takes its name from an 1883 collection by [[Auguste Villiers de l'Isle-Adam|Villiers de l'Isle-Adam]], although previous examples had been provided by such writers as [[Edgar Allan Poe]]. Some critics use the label to refer only to non-supernatural horror stories, especially those that have nasty climactic twists, but it is applicable to any story whose conclusion exploits the cruel aspects of the 'irony of fate.'<ref name="Stableford2009">{{cite book|author=Brian Stableford|title=The A to Z of Fantasy Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UHc3XTdJBxQC&pg=PA85|date=13 August 2009|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-6345-3|pages=85–}}</ref> The collection from which the short-story genre of the conte cruel takes its name is ''Contes cruels'' (1883, tr. Sardonic Tales, 1927) by [[Auguste Villiers de l'Isle-Adam|Villiers de l'Isle-Adam]]. Also taking its name from this collection is ''[[Contes cruels (Mirbeau)|Contes cruels]]'' ("''Cruel Tales''"), a two-volume set of about 150 tales and short stories by the 19th-century French writer [[Octave Mirbeau]], collected and edited by [[Pierre Michel]] and Jean-François Nivet and published in two volumes in 1990 by Librairie Séguier.
Some noted writers in the conte cruel genre are [[Charles Birkin]], [[Maurice Level]], [[Patricia Highsmith]] <ref>François Riviere, [http://next.liberation.fr/culture/1995/02/06/patricia-highsmith-a-rejoint-les-eaux-profondes_124532 "Patricia Highsmith a rejoint les eaux profondes"] ''[[Libération]]'', 6th February 1995. Retrieved 13th January 2018.</ref> and [[Roald Dahl]], the latter of whom originated ''[[Tales of the Unexpected (book)|Tales of the Unexpected]]''. [[H. P. Lovecraft]] observed of Level's fiction in his essay ''Supernatural Horror in Literature'' (1927): "This type, however, is less a part of the weird tradition than a class peculiar to itself—the so-called conte cruel, in which the wrenching of the emotions is accomplished through dramatic tantalizations, frustrations, and gruesome physical horrors".<ref name="Lovecraft1964">{{cite book|author=Howard Phillips Lovecraft|title=At the Mountains of Madness|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CuWNI905KjIC&pg=PT188|year=1964|publisher=eBookIt.com|isbn=978-9949-9424-4-2|pages=188–}}</ref>
[[Brian M. Stableford]] has observed that, by the 1980s, the conte cruel was the standard narrative form of [[soft science fiction]],<ref name="Stableford2004">{{cite book|author=Brian M. Stableford|title=Historical Dictionary of Science Fiction Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nzmIPZg5xicC&pg=PA73|date=1 January 2004|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-4938-9|pages=73–}}</ref> in particular the works of [[Thomas M. Disch]] and [[John Sladek]].<ref name="Stableford2004"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

'''Corporate entertainment''' describes private events held by [[corporation]]s or [[business]]es for their staff, clients or stakeholders. These events can be for large audiences such as conventions and conferences, or smaller events such as retreats, holiday parties or even private [[concert]]s.
It is also commonly used to mean corporate hospitality, the process of entertaining guests at corporate events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.showsinabox.com/what-is-a-corporate-event/|title=What Is A Corporate Event? - Shows In a Box|date=2012-12-12|work=Shows In a Box|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en-US}}</ref>
The companies that provides corporate [[entertainment]] are called corporate event planners or corporate booking agencies.
== Types of corporate entertainment events == There are various types of corporate events that make use of entertainment. An opening general session may include entertainment that adds excitement and presents the overall theme of the meeting. Mixers or pre-dinner parties many times use entertainment meant to provide a backdrop for conversation, perhaps an acoustic ensemble or pre-recorded music. Awards or gala events, usually the last event in a series of meetings, can make use of many options, from [[celebrity]] entertainers to exciting bands providing dance music or other options that will leave the attendees with a feeling of excitement and looking forward to the next meeting. There are many different types of corporate entertainment.
=== Corporate team building === Corporate entertainment can also include a day of [[team building]] activities. These activities include traditional camp activities like tug of war, scavenger hunts, and relay races. They could also include sports such as volleyball, soccer, or basketball. The goal of team building corporate entertainment is to have employees recognize how the challenges of the activities relate to the workplace.<ref>Graves, Jada A. [http://money.usnews.com/money/careers/articles/2014/09/25/corporate-team-building-activities-the-good-the-bad-and-the-really-ugly/* "Corporate Team-Building Activities: The Good, the Bad and the Really Ugly"]. 25 Sept 2014</ref> Team chemistry, identifying strengths and attributes, understanding how to work through solving problems as one, and reflecting makes for fruitful team building.
=== Corporate awards events === Awards or gala events are usually lavish events that celebrate accomplishment or milestones of a person or group of people in similar industries. Often these events serve as fundraisers for a specific cause. In addition to celebrating and recognizing achievements, it allows attendees to network with others with similar backgrounds or professions.
=== Corporate holiday celebration events === Holiday celebration events are ways for companies or departments to celebrate holidays and to show appreciation to employees. Entertainment at these events vary from raffles and door prizes, [[mystery dinner]]s, music and an overall casual, social setting that can build social relationships. For Christmas celebrations, some companies have used the ''[[A Christmas Story]]'' theme.
=== Corporate seminars and educational events === Corporate seminars, workshops, symposiums, and conferences are more informative in nature and often focussed on educational purposes. A conference refers to a formal meeting where participants exchange their views on various topics. A seminar is a form of academic instruction, either at a university or offered by a commercial or professional organization. A workshop includes all the elements of the seminar, but with the largest portion emphasizing “hands-on-practice” or laboratory work. A symposium is a formal gathering in an academic setting where participants are experts in their fields. Entertainment for these events varies from kick-op brunches to start, special industry guest speakers, and mixers, dinners afterwards. There are also booths set up for trade shows to display a companies strengths and for better marketing.
=== Corporate charity events === Corporate charity events, whether concerts, golf tournaments, or anything else, play an important role in how businesses interact with the community. Corporate charity events unite people from all levels of the organization; such events are another form of team building which positively influence other aspects of work.
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Infobox bibliography | Image = | ImageSize = | Caption = | Alt = | Author =[[David Eddings]] | Novel = 26 | NovelLink = Novels | Option = 1 | OptionName = Background material }} This complete list of works by American fantasy author [[David Eddings]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fantasticfiction.com/e/david-eddings/|title=David Eddings bibliography|work=fantasticfiction.com}}</ref>
==Bibliography== Eddings' wife, '''Leigh Eddings''', was uncredited as co-author on several of his early books, but he later acknowledged that she contributed to them all. ("She thought up '[[Regina's Song]]' in that single afternoon, but it took me 20 years to figure out who the point-of-view character was.")
She was a credited co-author starting in the mid-1990s. It was [[Lester del Rey]] who believed that multi-authorships were a problem and that it would be better if David Eddings' name alone appeared on the books.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fantasybookreview.co.uk/David-Eddings/biography.html|title=David Eddings biography|work=fantasybookreview.co.uk|accessdate=19 August 2015}}</ref>
=== ''The Belgariad'' and ''The Malloreon'' === {{main|The Belgariad|The Malloreon}} ''The Belgariad'' is Eddings' first fantasy series; ''The Malloreon'' is the sequel. The books follow the adventures of [[Belgarion]], [[Characters in The Belgariad and The Malloreon#Protagonists|Polgara]], [[Characters in The Belgariad and The Malloreon#Protagonists|Belgarath]], their companions, and learning the Will and the Word.
==== ''The Belgariad'' series ==== # ''[[The Belgariad#Pawn of Prophecy|Pawn of Prophecy]]'' (1982) # ''[[The Belgariad#Queen of Sorcery|Queen of Sorcery]]'' (1982) # ''[[The Belgariad#Magician's Gambit|Magician's Gambit]]'' (1983) # ''[[The Belgariad#Castle of Wizardry|Castle of Wizardry]]'' (1984) # ''[[The Belgariad#Enchanters' End Game|Enchanters' End Game]]'' (1984)
==== ''The Malloreon'' series ==== # ''[[The Malloreon#Guardians of the West|Guardians of the West]]'' (1987) # ''[[The Malloreon#King of the Murgos|King of the Murgos]]'' (1988) # ''[[The Malloreon#Demon Lord of Karanda|Demon Lord of Karanda]]'' (1988) # ''[[The Malloreon#Sorceress of Darshiva|Sorceress of Darshiva]]'' (1989) # ''[[The Malloreon#The Seeress of Kell|The Seeress of Kell]]'' (1991)
==== Books related to ''The Belgariad'' and ''The Malloreon'' ==== * ''[[Belgarath the Sorcerer]]'' (1995) with Leigh Eddings * ''[[Polgara the Sorceress]]'' (1997) with Leigh Eddings * ''[[The Rivan Codex]]'' (1998) with Leigh Eddings
=== ''The Elenium'' and ''The Tamuli'' === {{main|The Elenium|The Tamuli}} ''The Elenium'' and its sequel ''The Tamuli'' feature the Pandion [[Knight]] Sparhawk and his comrades.
==== ''The Elenium'' series ==== # ''[[The Elenium#The Diamond Throne|The Diamond Throne]]'' (1989) # ''[[The Elenium#The Ruby Knight|The Ruby Knight]]'' (1990) # ''[[The Elenium#The Sapphire Rose|The Sapphire Rose]]'' (1991)
==== ''The Tamuli'' series ==== # ''[[The Tamuli#Domes of Fire|Domes of Fire]]'' (1992) # ''[[The Tamuli#The Shining Ones|The Shining Ones]]'' (1993) # ''[[The Tamuli#The Hidden City|The Hidden City]]'' (1994)
===''The Dreamers'' series=== {{main|The Dreamers (novel series)}} ''The Dreamers'' series (written with Leigh Eddings) tells the story of a war between the Elder Gods and their allies and an entity known as the Vlagh. # ''The Elder Gods'' (2003) # ''The Treasured One'' (2004) # ''Crystal Gorge'' (2005) # ''The Younger Gods'' (2006)
=== Standalone fantasy novels === * ''[[The Redemption of Althalus]]'' (2000) with Leigh Eddings, is a standalone novel about a thief who mends his ways.
===Non-fantasy=== * ''[[High Hunt]]'' (1973) – a story revolving around a hunting expedition that spirals out of control. * [[The Losers (1992)|''The Losers'' (1992)]] – a story about a man struggling to rebuild his life after an accident. * ''[[Regina's Song]]'' (2002) with Leigh Eddings – a thriller about a woman after the murder of her twin sister.

revision.comment: The name of the author of the third translation was the wrong way round ("Rocco, Sinisgalli") - in the other names the surname comes first. "Rocco" is a common Italian first name, and "Sinisgalli" cannot be anything but a surname, so I've changed this to "Sinisgalli, Rocco".~~~~
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Della Pittura Alberti perspective vanishing point.jpg|thumb|300px|Figure from ''Della pittura'' showing the [[vanishing point]]]] [[File:Della Pittura Alberti perspective circle to ellipse.jpg|thumb|Alberti's figure showing how a circle projected as an ellipse]] [[File:Della Pittura Alberti perspective pillars on grid.jpg|thumb|Figure showing pillars in [[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]] on a grid]]
'''''De pictura''''' (English: "On Painting") is a treatise written by the Italian architect and art theorist [[Leon Battista Alberti]]. The first version, written in vernacular Italian in 1435 under the title '''''Della pittura''''', was for a general audience. The Latin version, the ''De pictura'' of 1439–41, was more technical and intended for scholars.<ref name="StAndrews">{{cite web |last1=O'Connor |first1=J. J. |last2=Robertson |first2=E. F. |title=Mathematics and art - perspective |url=http://www-groups.dcs.st-and.ac.uk/history/HistTopics/Art.html |publisher=University of St Andrews |accessdate=21 October 2016 |date=January 2003}}</ref> The work is the first in a trilogy of treatises on the "Major arts" which had a widespread circulation during the [[Renaissance]], the others being ''[[De re aedificatoria]]'' ("On Architecture", 1454) and ''De statua'' ("On Sculpture", 1462).
==Context==
Alberti was a member of [[history of Florence|Florentine]] family exiled in the 14th century, who was able to return in Florence only from 1434, in the following of the Papal court during the [[Council of Florence]]. Here he knew contemporary art innovators such as [[Filippo Brunelleschi]], [[Donatello]] and [[Masaccio]], with whom he shared an interest for [[Renaissance humanism]] and classical art. Alberti was the first post-classical writer to produce a work of [[art theory]], as opposed to works about the function of religious art or art techniques, and reflected the developing [[Italian Renaissance art]] of his day.
==Work==
===Contents===
Book I: a simple introduction for young boys, in preparation for studying painting<ref name=Wright>{{cite journal |last1=Wright |first1=D. R. Edward |title=Alberti's De Pictura: Its Literary Structure and Purpose |journal=Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes |date=1984 |volume=47 |pages=52–71 |jstor=751438}}</ref>
Book II: a survey of types of painting for teenage trainees in a workshop<ref name=Wright/>
Book III: advice to the adult painter on how to perfect his skill<ref name=Wright/>
===Approach=== {{further information|Mathematics and art}}
''De pictura'' aimed to describe systematically the figurative arts through "geometry". Alberti divided painting into three parts: *''Circumscriptio'' (Italian: ''disegno''), consisting in drawing the bodies' contour *'' Compositio'' (''commensuratio'' in the Italian version of the treatise), including tracing the lines joining the bodies * ''Receptio luminum'' (''color''), taking into consideration colors and light.
The treatise contained an analysis of all the techniques and painting theories known at the time, in this surpassing medieval works such as ''The book of Art'' by [[Cennino Cennini]] (1390). ''De pictura'' also includes the first description of linear geometric perspective around 1416; Alberti credited the discovery to [[Brunelleschi]], and dedicated the 1435 edition to him.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Edgerton|first1=Samuel Y.|title=Brunelleschi's mirror, Alberti's window, and Galileo's 'perspective tube'|journal=História, Ciências, Saúde-Manguinhos|date=October 2006|volume=13|issue=suppl. 0|doi=10.1590/S0104-59702006000500010|url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0104-59702006000500010}}</ref>
Alberti argued that multi-figure history painting was the noblest form of art, as being the most difficult, which required mastery of all the others, because it was a visual form of history, and because it had the greatest potential to move the viewer. He placed emphasis on the ability to depict the interactions between the figures by gesture and expression.<ref>[[Anthony Blunt|Blunt, Anthony]], ''Artistic Theory in Italy, 1450-1660'', (1985) [1940] [[OUP]], {{ISBN|0-19-881050-4}}, pages 11–12</ref><ref>Barlow, Paul, [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:9MoshlkHpFYJ:www.manchesteruniversitypress.co.uk/uploads/docs/s1_23.pdf+Paul+Barlow+Professor&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjcjev4zZWsyXRk2Qb0TAbQHs52uwq7cmMmRBnlY97ah2aGpKYtVsGu-QOIeMciCrUfH45N1knB0NFikusclJybCwP5TMoAMaQJNS8TPzZFOBvOQvtUrmEPUT--Kqw8tmhvKr8G&sig=AHIEtbSRK7DWVGwdLbYF38jvUAihfTFS0Q "The Death of History Painting in Nineteenth-Century Art?" PDF], ''Visual Culture in Britain'', Volume 6, Number 1, Summer 2005, pages 1–13</ref>
''De pictura'' relied heavily on references to art in classical literature; in fact [[Giotto]]'s huge ''[[Navicella (mosaic)|Navicella]]'' in mosaic at [[Old St. Peter's Basilica]] in Rome (now effectively lost) was the only{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} modern (post-classical) work described in it.<ref>{{cite journal |authorlink=Svetlana Alpers |author=Alpers, Svetlana Leontief |title=Ekphrasis and Aesthetic Attitudes in Vasari's Lives |journal=Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes |volume=23 |issue=3/4 |date=July 1960 |pages=190–192 |jstor=750591}}</ref>
==Influence== [[File:Leonardo Da Vinci - Annunciazione.jpeg|thumb|350px|The accurate perspective in [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s paintings such as his ''[[Annunciation (Leonardo)|Annunciation]]'' (1475–1480) derives from Alberti's ''De pictura''.]]
''De pictura'' influenced the work of artists including [[Donatello]], [[Ghiberti]], [[Botticelli]], and [[Ghirlandaio]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Lefaivre, Liane |title=Leon Battista Alberti's Hypnerotomachia Poliphili: Re-Cognizing the Architectural Body in the Early Italian Renaissance |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ocUH6f3l_E8C&pg=PA135 |year=2005 |publisher=MIT Press |isbn=978-0-262-62195-3 |pages=135–}}</ref> His treatment of [[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]] was the most influential of his recommendations, having a powerful effect on [[Leonardo da Vinci]], and through him on the whole Italian renaissance.<ref name=Ackerman>{{cite book |last=Ackerman |first=James S. |title=Distance Points: Essays in Theory and Renaissance Art and Architecture |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W7EadYT-LTUC&pg=PA87 |year=1994 |publisher=MIT Press |isbn=978-0-262-51077-6 |pages=86–87 |quote=No particular precept in the first part of De pictura had as pervasive an impact as the following section on perspective construction; the specific recommendations on color and shadow were ineffectual.. But the incalculable change that Leonardo wrought was directly dependent on Alberti's vision of art as a branch .. of optics}}</ref>
Alberti made at least 29 uses of [[Pliny the Elder]]'s ''[[Natural History (Pliny)|Natural History]]'', deriving his key themes of simplicity and seriousness directly from Pliny. For example, Alberti advised artists to use colour with restraint, and to paint in the effect of gold rather than using actual gold in their paintings. Gold did indeed vanish from Italian paintings of the second part of the 15th century. Artists however found their own ways to paint with restraint, rather than following Alberti's actual instructions directly. Similarly, he encouraged artists to add black when modelling shapes, rather than only adding white as [[Cennino Cennini]] had advised in his c. 1390 ''Il Libro dell'Arte''. This advice had the effect of making Italian renaissance paintings more sombre. Alberti was here perhaps following Pliny's description of the dark varnish used by Apelles.<ref name=Ackerman/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Grafton |first1=Anthony |last2=Most |first2=Glenn W. |last3=Settis |first3=Salvatore |title=The Classical Tradition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LbqF8z2bq3sC&pg=PA214 |year=2010 |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0-674-03572-0|page=214}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=January 2009}}
A '''deviancy amplification spiral''' (also called '''deviance amplification''') is a [[media hype]] phenomenon defined by [[media critic]]s as a cycle of increasing numbers of reports on a category of [[antisocial behaviour]] or some other 'undesirable' event, leading to a [[moral panic]].
==Origin of term== The process of deviancy amplification was first described by Leslie T. Wilkins.<ref>Wilkins, Leslie T. (Tavistock Publications 1964) [Routledge 2001] Social Deviance: Social Policy, Action, and Research (Retrieved 26 April 2014)</ref> [[Stanley Cohen (sociologist)|Stanley Cohen]] adopted this theory in ''Folk Devils and Moral Panics'', and applied it to the case scenario of the "Mods and Rockers", in which he identified the concept of the deviancy amplification spiral.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
==Process== According to Cohen, the spiral starts with some '[[Deviance (sociology)|deviant]]' act. Usually the deviance is [[crime|criminal]], but it can also involve lawful acts considered morally repugnant by a large segment of society. With the new focus on the issue, hidden or borderline examples that would not themselves have been newsworthy are reported, [[Confirmation bias|confirming the 'pattern]]'.
Reported cases of such 'deviance' are often presented as just 'the ones we know about' or the '[[wiktionary:tip of the iceberg|tip of the iceberg]]', an assertion that is nearly impossible to disprove immediately. For a variety of reasons, the less sensational aspects of the spiraling story that would help the public keep a rational perspective (such as statistics showing that the behavior or event is actually less common or less harmful than generally believed) tend to be ignored by the press.
As a result, minor problems begin to look serious and rare events begin to seem common. Members of the public are motivated to keep informed on these events, leading to high readership for the stories, feeding the spiral. The resulting publicity has the potential to increase the deviant behavior by glamorizing it, or by making it seem common or acceptable. In the next stage, public concern typically forces the police and the law enforcement system to focus more resources on dealing with the specific deviancy than it warrants.
Judges and magistrates then come under public pressure to deal out harsher sentences and politicians pass new laws to increase their popularity by giving the impression that they are dealing with the perceived threat. The responses by those in authority tend to reinforce the public's fear, while the media continue to report police and other law enforcement activity, amplifying the spiral.
The theory does not contend that moral panics always include the deviancy amplification spiral.
[[Eileen Barker]] asserts that the controversy surrounding certain [[new religious movements]] can turn violent in a deviancy amplification spiral.<ref>Barker, Eileen, [http://www.fathom.com/feature/121938/ Introducing New Religious Movements] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014065725/http://www.fathom.com/feature/121938/ |date=October 14, 2007 }}, Retrieved 22 November 2006.</ref> In his autobiography, [[Lincoln Steffens]] details how news reporting can be used to create the impression of a [[crime|crime wave]] where there is none, in the chapter "I Make a Crime Wave".
Button and Tunley<ref>Button, Mark and Tunley, Martin (2015) Explaining Fraud Deviancy Attenuation in the United Kingdom. Crime, Law and Social Change, 63: 49-64 [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10611-015-9551-0]</ref> have also presented a theory that offers the opposite to deviancy amplification, which they call deviancy attenuation. In this they argue using the case of fraud that there are some large problems, which those in positions of power are able to attenuate through not accurately measuring it, leading to statistics which under-estimate the problem, leading to less resources dedicated to it, re-enforcing the belief of those in power it is not a problem.
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Availability heuristic]] *[[Crowd psychology]] *[[Culture of fear]] *[[Folk devil]] *[[Gel bracelet]] *[[Jenkem]] *[[Junk food news]] *[[Knockout (violent game)]] *[[Mass hysteria]] *[[Mass media]] *[[Mean world syndrome]] *[[Missing white woman syndrome]] *[[Rainbow party (sexuality)|Rainbow party]] *[[Representativeness heuristic]] *[[Sensationalism]] *[[Sex party (group sex)|Sex party]] *[[Social control]] *[[Yellow journalism]] {{div col end}}
