{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} [[File:Richard Wittington and his Cat.jpg|right|thumb|280px|Richard Whittington and his Cat, considered a "fictitious portrait".
{{right|{{small|—[[Guillaume Philippe Benoist|Benoist]]'s engraving, after a lost painting at [[Mercers' Hall]], from ''The New Wonderful Museum, and Extraordinary Magazine'' (1805).{{citation|last1=Granger|first1=William|last2=Caulfield|first2=James|chapter=History of the Memorable Sir Richard Whittington|title=The New Wonderful Museum, and Extraordinary Magazine|volume=3|publisher=Alex. Hogg & Co.|year=1805|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rKU0AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA1420|page=1420}}}}}}]] [[File:Adventuresofwhit00newyiala 0007.jpg|right|thumb|280px|Dick Whittington buys a cat from a woman.
{{small|—Colored cut from a children's book published in New York, c. 1850 (Dunigan's edition).}}]] '''''Dick Whittington and His Cat''''' is the English [[folklore]] surrounding the real-life [[Richard Whittington]] (c. 1354–1423), wealthy merchant and later [[Lord Mayor of London]]. The legend describes his rise from poverty-stricken childhood with the fortune he made through the sale of his cat to a rat-infested country. However, the real Whittington did not come from a poor family of common stock, and there is no compelling evidence supporting the stories about the cat, or even whether he owned one. There is also conjecture that certain aspects of the story, in fact, relate to a different occupant of the office of Lord Mayor, [[William Craven (Lord Mayor of London)|Sir William Craven]] who was Lord Mayor in 1610, around the same date as the first written records of the story, and whose life had much more in common with that reflected in the story. Another element in the legend is that Dick attempted to flee his service as a [[scullery|scullion]] one night, heading towards home (or reached [[Highgate Hill]] in later tradition), but was dissuaded by the sound of [[St Mary-le-Bow#Bells|Bow bells]], which promised he would be mayor of London one day. Since the pre-[[Victorian era]], the story has been a favourite subject of English [[pantomime]], especially during [[Christmas and holiday season|Christmas season]]. ==Overview== Written forms date from the early 1600s, long after the death of the historical Whittington. A drama play (1604–5) and ballad (1605) are lost, and [[Richard Johnson (16th century)|Richard Johnson]]'s ballad of 1612 is the earliest surviving piece that refer to Whittington making his fortune with his cat. This early ballad already contains the tradition that Whittington fled his {{linktext|scullion}}'s service and traveled towards home, but was beckoned back by the London bells which predicted his future of becoming mayor. It has also been speculated that the story, in reality, had its origins as a satire against the humble origins of a different Lord Mayor of London, [[William Craven (Lord Mayor of London)|Sir William Craven]] , who held the office in 1610. This theory is supported by the chronology of the story's origins, and by the fact that Sir William Craven's life had many more real parallels to the story than that of Sir Richard Whittington, who, unlike Craven, was never born into poverty. It seems likely that the story combines elements of both. The earliest known prose rendition is ''The Famous and Remarkable History of Sir Richard Whittington'' by "T. H." ([[Thomas Heywood]]), published 1656 in [[chapbook]] form, which specified that the bells were those of Bow Church ([[St Mary-le-Bow]]), and that the boy heard them at [[Bunhill fields|Bunhill]]. Common chapbooks of a later period wrote that the boy reached as far as [[Holloway, London|Holloway]] on the night he fled. Links to this village has not been corroborated in early folklore or literature, and is thought to be an 18th-century invention. But based on this tradition, the landmark [[Whittington Stone]] at the foot of [[Highgate Hill]] is commonly perceived to be the place where Dick Whittingon stopped and heard the famous bells. The story was adapted into [[Puppetry|puppet play]] by [[Martin Powell (puppetry)|Martin Powell]] in the early 18th century. Later, it has been performed as stage [[pantomime]]s and children's plays. It has also been retold as a children's story by a number of printers and authors to this day. A number of foreign and medieval analogues exist that exhibit the motif ("Whittington's cat" motif, N411.2), where the hero obtains wealth by selling a cat, typically in a rodent-infested place direly in need of one. The tale is catalogued [[Aarne–Thompson classification system|Aarne–Thompson]] (AT) tale type 1651, "Whittington's Cat". ==Synopsis== The following summary gives a comparison of three textual sources. B = Johnson's ballad, H = prose by [[Thomas Heywood|Heywood]], signed T. H. (Wheatley ed.);{{Efn|Entitled ''The Famous and Remarkable History of Sir Richard Whittington'' .}}{{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|pp=1–37}} C = Late chapbook (18th to 19th-century printing by J. Cheney):{{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|pp=xxxii–xlii}} ;To London Dick Whittington was a poor orphan boy, languishing in [[Lancashire]] (B), or some unnamed place in the country (H, C).{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|Lysons' investigations determined that the historical Whittington family base was in a village in [[Gloucestershire]] by Richard's time. But popular legend localize him variously to "Taunton Dean," "Ellesmere in Shropshire," or "some unknown town in Hereforshire".{{Harvp|Besant|Rice|1881|p=27}}}} He set off to seek his fortune in London (B, H, C), enticed by the rumour that [[London streets are paved with gold|its streets were paved with gold]] (C). But he soon found himself cold and hungry,It is winter season according to H. and fell asleep at the gate of the home of a wealthy merchant named Fitzwarren (H, C).The ballad does not name the merchant, but the prose versions supply the name of Fitzwarren, the mercer with whom the historical Richard Whittingon apprenticed. Fitzwarren gave him lodging and hired him to be the [[wikt:scullion|scullion]] in the kitchen (B, H, C). ;Dick and his cat In the prose versions, an account of the Dick Whittington's cat subsequently follows, but in the ballad, it is preceded by Dick's flight and church bells episode. In the prose legend, Dick is provided quarter at the Fitzwarrens' [[garret]] (room in the attic) (H, C), which was infested with rats and mice (H, C). But Dick owned a cat (B, H, C), that the prose versions say he had bought for a penny he earned by shining shoes (H, C)."for going of an errand, or for making clean boots or shooes [sic.] or the like" (H); "a gentleman... gave... a penny for brushing his shoes" (C) The cat controlled his rodent problem, which made her an indispensable companion. When Fitzwarren organized a trade expedition sending the merchant ship ''Unicorn'' (H), Dick's cat was "ventured" to this mission to be sold for profit abroad (B, H, C). The versions also differ regarding the circumstances: either Dick relinquished the cat of his own volition, hoping its sale in a foreign land might reap a "store of gold" towards the fulfillment of the omen of the bells (B), or, Dick was compelled to do so by Fitzwarren, who maintained a steadfast rule that everyone in his household should have some article of worth riding on the venture, with due dividends forthcoming from the proceeds (H, C). ;Flight, and the bells tolling Dick became disenchanted with the scullion's lot and attempted to flee, either because he received room and board only for his labours and was denied monetary wages (B), or because the kitchen maid (H) or female cook named Mrs. Cicely (C) abused and physically beat him beyond his tolerance. He ran as far away as [[Bunhill Fields|Bunhill]] (H) or [[Holloway, London|Holloway]] (C), where he heard "London Bells" (B), [[Bow bells]] (C), or the bells of "Bow Church" (H), that seemed to be telling him,
"Turn again Whittington, Lord Mayor of London" (H).
which persuaded him to retrace his steps. (The wording of the bells' message differ slightly according to the textual source). ;Rags to riches The ship was driven off course to the [[Barbary Coast]], where the Moorish king purchased the entire cargo for a load of gold, and insisted on entertaining the English traders with a feast. But the banquet was swarmed with rats and mice, whereby the English "factor" (business agent) informed their hosts that they were in possession of a creature which could exterminate these vermin (H, C). Thus Dick Whittington's cat was immediately put to the test, chasing and destroying the rodents. The Moors, even more pleased to learn that the cat was pregnant, paid more (H) (or ten times more (C)) for the cat than the rest of the cargo combined. The ship returned to London and Fitzwarren who was apprised of the success of the venture (at his home on [[Leadenhall Street|Leadenhall]] (H)), summoned the besmirched scullion Dick Whittington to the parlour (H) (or compting-room (C)) and sat him in a seat, addressing him in dignified fashion as Master (H) or Mr. Whittington. Dick was upset at first that this was being done in mockery, but Fitzwarren insisted it was all in earnest, explaining that the profits from the ship now made Dick a richer man than himself (C, H). Dick married his former master's daughter Alice Fitzwarren (C, H), and joined his father-in-law in his business (H). In time, Whittington became the Lord Mayor of London three times, just as the bells had predicted. Whittington's acts of charity included the building of a [[College (canon law)|college]], a church (B, H, C), and [[Newgate Prison]] (B, H, C). He also burnt the bonds he owned, which the Crown had issued to fund the war (B, H). ==Whittington Stone== {{Main|Whittington Stone}} Today, on [[Highgate Hill]] in front of [[Whittington Hospital]], there is a statue in honour of Whittington's legendary cat on the site where, according to late versions of the story, the distant [[Bow Bells]] beckoned young Dick back to London to claim his fortune.{{citation |last=Cosh |first=Mary|author-link=Mary Cosh |title=A History of Islington|publisher=Historical Publications |year=2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fRwXAQAAIAAJ |page=15 |isbn=978-0-9486-6797-8}} The cat statue was placed atop the [[Whittington Stone]] later, in 1964.{{citation |last1=Westwood |first1=Jennifer |author-link1=Jennifer Westwood |last2=Simpson |first2=Jacqueline |author-link2=Jacqueline Simpson |title=The Lore of Scotland: A Guide to Scottish Legends |publisher=Penguin |year=2006 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l3USAQAAIAAJ |page=474 |isbn=978-0-1410-2103-4}} The site of the Whittington Stone lies within confines of "Upper Holloway" according to 19th century writers,{{cite book |last=Tomlins |first=Thomas Edlyne |title=Yseldon: Perambulation of Islington |place=London |publisher=James S. Hodson |year=1858 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pj0QAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA140 |pages=128, 140–143 (illustr.)}} which corresponds with some chapbooks that say the boy ran away to as far away as "Holloway".{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|pp=iii, xxxiv}}{{Refn|group="lower-alpha" |Actually [[Upper Holloway]] ends at the foot of Highgate Hill and was once known as Lower or South Highgate,{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} until the underground station was renamed to Archway. Therefore the sculpture of Whittington's cat is currently situated at the foot of Highgate Hill in ''Archway''.}} It is not clear how far back this marker can be dated. Whittington biographer [[Samuel Lysons (priest)|Lysons]] felt it stood there as a marker for "many centuries", even if it was actually just the debris of an old cross with only the [[plinth]] or base remaining, as some had suggested.{{sfnp|Lysons|1860|p=24}} [[Henry B. Wheatley]] argued that Whittington's association to "Holloway" must have been a later embellishment, as it is lacking in the early T. H. text (in which the boy only goes as far as Bunhill, just north of London). He thus does not think the stone could be dated anywhere near-contemporaneously to Whittington's lifespan, but he does allow that a purported stone was removed in 1795, so that the tradition at least predated the relocation of [[Whittington College]] to Highgate.{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|Note that [[St Michael Paternoster Royal|Whittington College]] was relocated again in c. 1960s to its current location, and the Stone is no longer as near the College as once were.{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|p=iii}}}} Wheatley also observed that Holloway was at such a distance that it would have been difficult for a child to have reached there by foot and returned the next morning.{{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|p=iii}}: "before the cook had risen". and that it was only barely within earshot of the bells of "Bow Church".{{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|p=iii}}: "it would be less easy to hear [[Bow Bells]]".{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|The general area ([[Islington]]) was on the outer limits of where the bell could be heard in 1851, the year of [[The Great Exhibition]] (undisclosed source). At the launch of the Times Atlas of London, a sound map of London was commissioned to show how far the sound of the bells reached in 2012, and the audible range fell far short. However in 1851, it could be heard the City of London, across Islington, Hackney, Tower Hamlets and into parts of Camden, Southwark, Newham and Waltham Forest.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2164799/Bow-Bells-mark-area-true-Londoners-drowned-capitals-noise-pollution.html |last=Parsons |first=Chris |title=Could Cockneys soon be brown bread? Sound of Bow Bells that define 'true' Londoners 'are being drowned out by capital's noise pollution' |journal=Daily Maildate=26 June 2012}} However in Dick Whittington's time, ambient noise levels were fewer, and could have been clearly heard from the foot of Highgate Hill, according to [[Christopher Winn (writer)|Christopher Winn]], who cites another studies in the 1990s.{{cite book|last=Winn |first=Christopher |author-link=Christopher Winn (writer) |title=I Never Knew That About London |publisher=Macmillan |date=2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LtKszbSereMC&pg=PA43 |page=43 |isbn=9-781-2500-0151-1}}}} ==Publication history== The earliest recorded instance of the folklore in written form is a registry notice dated 1604-5 for a theatrical play. The drama ''The History of Richard Whittington, of his lowe byrth, his great fortune'' was licensed for the stage 1604–1605. Based on the only remaining evidence, which comes from the record at the [[Stationers' Registers]], there is no proof beyond doubt whether the play accounted for Dick's rise from "lowe birth" by means of a cat, but it is considered likely, since a play from the contemporary period entitled ''[[Eastward Hoe]]'' (1605) makes an explicit cat association with the line: "When the famous fable of Whittington and his puss shall be forgotten". This line also stands as the earliest surviving literary reference of Whittington and his cat.{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|p=viii}} ===Ballad=== A lost ballad is also known to have existed from the [[Stationers' Register]] of 1605. It records "A ballad, called The vertuous Lyfe and memorable death of Sr Ri: Whittington mercer sometymes Lo. Maior of the honorable Citie of London" licensed on 16 July 1605 to be printed by John Wright.Recorded in the same Stationers' Registers as the drama, {{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|p=viii}} The earliest surviving complete text of the legend in any form is the ballad written by [[Richard Johnson (16th century)|Richard Johnson]] on the subject. The 17-[[Octave (poetry)|octave]] piece, included in Johnson's ''Crowne Garland of Goulden Roses'' (1612), begins with the following lines:
"Here must I tell the praise / Of worthie Whittington..."
This ballad of 1612 already contains the tradition that the hero made an attempt to flee his service as a scullion and headed towards "his country", but was persuaded to abort his flight when the London bells beckoned him back, seeming to tell him "Whittington, back return" and pronouncing the omen that he would eventually become Lord Mayor. The ballad goes on to tell{{Efn|As already noted, in the prose and chap-book, the cat is introduced before the bells.}} how Whittington had a very humble past working as a kitchen [[wikt:scullion|scullion]], but that he "had a cat...And by it wealth he gat".{{sfnp|Johnson|1612|pp=20–25}}Quoted from ''A Collection of Old Ballads'' 1823 (actually 1723), vol. i., p. 130 {{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|pp=ix–xiv}} This ballad was sung to the tune of "Dainty come thou to me".{{sfnp|Johnson|1612|pp=20–25}}{{citation|last=Philips|first=Ambrose|chapter=XVI. Sir Richard Whittington's Advancement|title=A Collection of Old Ballads|volume=1|publisher=J. Roberts|year=1723|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8fzWAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA130 |pages=130–137}}Johnson's original work is catalogued STC (2nd ed.) 14672, and viewable from Early English Books Online. [[William Chappell (writer)|Chappell]] prints the musical notation to a tune that accompanied the ballad of Richard Whittington, which he suggests may be the same one as "Dainty".{{sfnp|Chappell|Macfarren|1859|p=517}} Of intermediate date is a version entitled "An Old Ballad of Whittington and his Cat," printed and sold in [[Aldermary Church]] Yard, London, dated 1750(?). A copy is owned by the [[Bodleian library]] (bequest of the [[Francis Douce]] collection),{{cite web|url=http://ballads.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/view/edition/23430 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202152354/http://ballads.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/view/edition/23430 |archive-date=2014-02-02 |title=An old ballad of Whittington and his cat (Bod23430) |work=Broadside Ballads Online |author=Bodleian Libraries}} (ESTC: N10713) and in the U.S., by the [[Huntington Library]]{{plain link|url=http://cdm16003.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15150coll3/id/5588 |name=Huntington library copy}} (ESTC N68225). and [[Yale University]].{{plain link|url=http://images.library.yale.edu/walpoleweb/oneitem.asp?imageId=lwlpr25497 |name=Yale University, Lewis Walpole Library copy}} (ESTC N068225) These copies show the same woodcut illustrations. A later edition dated to 1773 was part of the [[Roxburghe Ballads|Roxburghe Collection]] of [[Broadside Ballads]].{{Efn|The artwork reprinted on p. 585 of the ''Roxburghe Ballads'' book differs from the art in the earlier edition.}}{{Harvp|Chappell|1895|loc=''Roxburghe Ballads'', VII, pp. 585–586}} Other [[broadside ballad]] printings have been made into the 19th century. A version entitled ''London's Glory and Whittington's Renown; or, A Looking-Glass for Citizens of London'', printed for R. Burton at the Horse-Shoe, in West Smithfield, c. 1650, has been reprinted from the [[Roxburghe Ballads|Roxburghe]] collection.{{Harvp|Chappell|1895|loc=''Roxburge Ballads'', VII, pp. 582–4}} Another is a broadside published in London by J. Pitts (between 1802 and 1819).{{citation|editor-last=Lane |editor-first=William Collidge |author-link=William Collidge Lane |title=Catalogue of English and American Chapbooks and Broadside Ballads |series=Biographical Contributions 54 |year=1902 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=13VIAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA66 |page=66}}, No. 1160 (broadside published London, J. Pitts){{cite web|url=http://ballads.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/view/edition/5255 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019064706/http://ballads.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/search/printer/Pitts,%20J./?query=&f_Subjects=Whittington%2C%20Richard%2C%20d.%201423 |archive-date=2015-10-19 |title=An old ballad of Whittington and his cat (Bod5255) |work=Broadside Ballads Online |author=Bodleian Libraries}} (ESTC: N10713) ===Earliest chapbook version=== [[File:History of Sir Richard Whittington(1770)-00-inset-detail.jpg|thumb|From title page of ''The Famous and Remarkable History of Sir Richard Whittington, Three Times Lord-Mayor of London'' (1770), Thomas and John Fleet, printers.
{{small|{{right|—Boston Public Library}}}}]] The story was also set in prose, especially in the form of common [[chapbooks]]. ''The Famous and Remarkable History of Sir Richard Whittington'' by "T. H." (first edition, 1656) is the earliest extant chapbook version of the tale in the estimation of its editor [[Henry B. Wheatley]].{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|Wheatley (1885) used an undated copy assigned a conjectural date of "1670?".{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|pp=ii, xxv}} But a "1656" print date is given elsewhere.{{sfnp|Chappell|1895|loc=''Roxburge Ballads'', VII, p. 579}}}} The author's identity is only given as "T. H.", but the work is ascribable to [[Thomas Heywood]].{{cite book|ref=harv|editor-last=Watson|editor-first=George|contribution=Heywood, Thomas|title=The New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature|volume=3|year=1969|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gfA8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA2267|page=2267}}{{Harvp|Chappell|1895|loc=''Roxburghe Ballads'', VII, p. 579}} Heywood certainly knew the cat story, for it is spoken of by the cast of characters in his play ''If You Know Not Me, You Know Nobody'' (1606).The dialogue of "Dean Nowell" and "Hobson" are quoted in {{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|pp=viii}} ===Other chapbooks=== A number of other [[chapbook]] editions appeared,{{Efn|10 books are listed in {{harvp|Lane|1902}}, ''Catalogue of English and American Chapbooks'', p. 35, Nos. 601–610.}} such as the one datable to 1730.{{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|p=xxv}} Perhaps the latest chapbook example is ''The Adventures of Sir Richard Whittingon'', printed by J. Cheney, 1788–1808De Freitas (2004), ''The Banbury chapbooks'', p. 34 which is quoted in full by Wheatley in his introduction. The later chapbooks contain embellishements{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|pp=ii–v}} such as London being a town with the reputation of being paved with gold, or the boy reaching Holloway, which is several times farther (than Bunhill).{{citation|last=Darton |first=Frederick Joseph Harvey |author-link=Frederick Joseph Harvey Darton |title=Children's Books in England: Five Centuries of Social Life |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2011 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-LfjGWB6OOcC&pg=PA93 |page=93 |isbn=978-1-1080-3381-7}} The localization in Holloway or [[Highgate Hill]] that appeared in common chapbooks is not found in any early versions,{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|p=iii}} and Wheatley believed it to be an 18th-century invention.{{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|p=i}}: "his change of mind at Highgate Hill.. an invention of the eighteenth century". "Bunhill" in T.H.'s ''History'' may also be an invention, but Wheatley dates that text to 1670. Holloway is situated in a historically inconsistent direction since it lies up north, which contradicts the tradition that the boy was fleeing towards home;{{Efn|To "his country" as given in the Ballad of 1612.}} the real Whittington's place of origin being Gloucester, lying westward. ===Modern printings=== The artist [[George Cruikshank]] published an illustrated version of the story in about 1820.Cruikshank, George. [https://archive.org/details/historyofdickwhi00cruiiala ''The history of Dick Whittington, Lord Mayor of London: with the adventures of his cat''], Banbury, c. 1820 The American [[Joseph Jacobs]] printed a version that is a composite of three chapbook texts in his ''English Fairy Tales'' (1890).{{Harvp|Jacobs|1890|loc="Whittington and his Cat", 167–178, 248 (notes)}} [[Cynthia Harnett]]'s ''[[Ring Out Bow Bells!]]'' (1953) is a retelling of the legend. ==Origins== [[File:Guildhall 20130324 132.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Dick Whittington and His Cat, a statue in the [[Guildhall, London|Guildhall]], London.{{right|{{small|—Laurence Tindall (1999).}}{{cite web|url=http://www.laurencetindall.co.uk/dickw.html|title=Dick Whittington |work=Laurence Tindall:sculptor |date=4 February 2009 |last=Tindall |first=Laurence}}}}]] The story is only loosely based on the life of Richard Whittington. Although Alice Fitzwarren, Dick's love interest in the play, is named after the historical Richard Whittington's wife, the cat story cannot be traced to any early historical source,{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|p=v}} and there is insufficient evidence that Whittington ever owned a cat.{{sfnp|Pickering|Morley|1993|p=65}}{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Hahn |first=Daniel |author-link=Daniel Hahn|title=Dick Whittington |work=The Oxford Companion to Children's Literature |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2015 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mb66BwAAQBAJ&pg=PA164 |page=164}} It is unknown how the cat story came to be attached to Whittington. Suggestions were made that the cat may be a corruption of the French ''achat'' meaning "purchase" ([[Henry Thomas Riley]]), or that it may come from the word "cat", another name for a coal-carrying boat which Whittington may have engaged in his business ([[Samuel Foote]]),{{Efn|Uttered by Sir Matthew Mite, a character in Foote's 1772 play ''[[The Nabob]]''}}{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|pp=xviii–xvix}}{{citation|last=Riley |first=Henry Thomas |author-link=Henry Thomas Riley |title=Liber Albus, Liber Custumarum Et Liber Horn |publisher=Longman, Brown |year=1859 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5_FCAAAAcAAJ&pg=PR18 |page=xviii–xix, note 3}} but these explanations were downplayed as implausible by later commentators.{{sfnp|Besant|Rice|1881|pp=132–133}}{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|p=v}} The [[Renold Elstracke|Elstracke]] portrait of Whittington and his cat probably dates to around 1605, and does not predate the times of the earliest literary adaptations. But commentators have strived to demonstrate that various pieces of art and architecture might be allusions to the legend of ''Dick Whittington and His Cat'' that predate the early 1600s (See [[#Relics|§Relics]]). ==Parallels== Antiquarians have noticed similarities to foreign tales of medieval origin, which tells of a character who makes his fortune selling his cat abroad. The motif was later catalogued "Whittington's cat" (N411.2) in [[Stith Thompson]]'s motif-index scheme.{{citation |last=Thompson |first=Stith |author-link=Stith Thompson|title=Motif-index of Folk-literature|publisher=Indiana University Press |year=1955|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qIJf9pCiVA8C&pg=PA178 |page=178}} Two Italian examples can be noted. One was told by [[Lorenzo Magalotti]] (d. 1732), regarding a 16th-century merchant Ansaldo degli Ormanni who made his fortune selling his cat to the king of the isle of Canary (Canaria).Published in: {{citation|last=Magalotti |first=Lorenzo |title=Novella |work=Novelle scelte dai piu celebri autori italiani |volume=IV |place=Torino |publisher=Giuseppe Pomba |year=1830 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PvAnX8VXFOcC&pg=PA112 |pages=112–115}}Parallel to Magalotti's tale stated, and synopsis given in: {{citation|last=Ouseley|first=William|title=Travels in Various Countries of the East, More Particularly Persia|volume=1|publisher=Rodwell and Martin|year=1819|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1G5BAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA171|pages=170, 171n}} Another, the ''Novella delle Gatte'' ("Tale of the she-cats") told by [[Piovano Arlotto]] (d. 1484), was published in the collection of witticisms (''Facetiae'') attributed to him.Printed in: {{cite book|last1=Mainardi|first1=Arlotto |title=Facezie, motti, buffonerie, et burle, del piovano Arlotto, del Gonnella, & del Barlacchia |year=1568 |place=Firenze |publisher=Appresso i Giunti}} (cited in {{Harvp|Keightley|1834|p=257n}}). For other editions, see e.g. {{cite book|last1=Mainardi|first1=Arlotto|chapter=Il Piovano, a un Prete, che fece mercanzia di palle dice la novella delle Gatte|title=Scelta di facezie, motti, burle, e buffonerie del Piovano Arlotto et altri autori |place=Lucca|publisher=per Salvatore e Gian Domenico Maresc|year=1601|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4EAVMlIIeJwC&pg=PA23|page=23}}Arlotto as an analogue was mentioned the piece by {{cite journal|last=Palgrave |first=Francis |author-link=Francis Palgrave |title=Antiquities of Nursery Literature (Review of Tabart, ''Fairy Tales'', 1818) |journal=The Quarterly Review |volume=XXI |year=1819 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gR5l2a2X4CAC&pg=PA99 |pages=99–100}} A similar tale is "also found in a German chronicle of the thirteenth century",{{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|p=vi}} but the tale is localized in [[Venice]], Italy. [[Albert of Stade|Albert von Stade]] in his ''Chronicon Alberti Abbati Stadensis'', writing on the events in 1175,{{Efn|His main topic was the development that year in the strife between the then-emperor ([[Manuel I Komnenos]]) and Venice.}} sidetracks into a legendary tale involving two early citizens of Venice. The rich man about to mount on a trade expedition offers to take a consignment of merchandise from the poor man (who could only afford 2 cats), and a great profit is realized to reward the poor friend. [[Thomas Keightley (historian)|Keightley]], who identified the tale as a parallel Whittington's, said the legend "was apparently an old one in Italy", although nothing was certain beyond it being known in the 13th century. A Persian story localized around Keish ([[Kish Island]]) tells of a certain widow's son who lived in the 10th century and made his fortune in India with his cat. This tale occurs in the ''Tarik al-Wasaf'' (''[[Wassaf|Tārīkḣ-i Waṣṣāf]]''), a 14th-century chronicle. The similarity was noted by [[James Justinian Morier|James Morier]], ''Second Journey'' (1818), and [[William Gore Ouseley]], ''Travels'' (1819).{{cite book|last=Morier|first=James|title=A second journey through Persia, Armenia, and Asia Minor, to Constantinople, between the year 1810 and 1816|publisher=Longman|year=1818|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AVRJAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA31|page=31}}{{citation|last=Ouseley|first=William|title=Travels in Various Countries of the East, More Particularly Persia|volume=1|publisher=Rodwell and Martin|year=1819|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1G5BAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA171 |pages=170 and 171n}}Morier was staffed to Persian ambassador, [[Gore Ouseley]], from whom he heard the tale. The younger Ouseley was stationed around the same period, 1810–, during his uncle's ambassadorship. A convenient source of the parallels is [[Thomas Keightley (historian)|Keightley]], who devoted Chapter VII of his ''Tales and Popular Fictions'' (1834) to the topic, boasting of the largest compilation of these parallels ever.{{citation|last=Keightley|chapter=Chapter VII Whittington and his cat – Danish legends – Italian stories – Persian legends|title=Tales and Popular Fictions: Their Resemblance, and Transmission from Country to Country|publisher=Whittaker and Co.|year=1834|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O4QSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA241|pages=241–266}} though he was not the first to make note of the parallels in published form. "Whittington and his Cat" is listed as one of the analogues grouped under [[Grimms' Fairy Tales|Grimms' tale]] KHM 70 ''[[:de:Die drei Glückskinder|Die drei Glückskinder]]'' ("[[The Three Sons of Fortune]]") in [[Johannes Bolte|Bolte]] and [[Jiří Polívka|Polívka]]'s ''Anmerkungen''. The list organizes parallel folktales by different language (including Dutch and German printings of "Whittington and his Cat").{{cite book|last=Bolte |first=Johannes |last2=Polívka |first2=Jiří |chapter=70. Die drei Glückskinder |title=Anmerkungen zu den Kinder- und Hausmärchen der Brüder Grimm |volume=2 |publisher=Dieterich |origyear=1915 |year=2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xm08DznR33oC&pg=PA74 |page=74|language=de}} Another parallel could be found in [[Puss in Boots]]. ===Tale type=== In modern folkloristics, tales with the same plot structure are classified under [[Aarne–Thompson classification system|Aarne–Thompson]] (AT) tale type 1651 "Whittington's Cat".Uther, Hans-Jörg (2004), ''The Types of International Folktales'', pp. 354–5 Examples of the tale type need not feature a cat, and the helper can be replaced by the angel St. Michael or St. Joseph.{{cite book|last=Pitré |first=Giuseppe |editor-last=Zipes|editor-first=Jack |editor-last2=Russo|editor-first2=Joseph |title=115. ''The Archangel St. Michael and his Devotee /S. Michaeli Arcangilu e un sò divotu |work=The Collected Sicilian Folk and Fairy Tales of Giuseppe Pitré |publisher=Routledge |year=2013|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z9-bUA1jYI0C&pg=PA890 |page=890}} ==Stage productions== The story has been adapted into puppet play, opera, dramatic play, and pantomime. ===Puppet play=== There is an early record of puppet performance of the legend, dating to [[Samuel Pepys]]'s diary of 21 September 1668, which reads: "To Southwark Fair, very dirty, and there saw the puppet show of Whittington, which was pretty to see".{{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|p=xvii}} At [[Covent Garden]], performances of "Whittington and his Cat" were put on by the puppeteer [[Martin Powell (puppetry)|Martin Powell]] (fl. 1710–1729).{{cite DNB| wstitle=Powell, Martin (DNB00) |last=Seccombe |first=Thomas |authorlink=Thomas Seccombe |volume=46 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zeIpAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA246 |page=246}} Powell was a successful showman, providing such a draw that the parish church of St. Paul would be drained of its congregation during hours of prayer when his plays were on.Steele, ''The Spectator'' No. 14, Friday, 16 March 1711; In [[#morley-spectator|Morley's annoted new edition]], pp. 24–26 An advertisement bill of the puppet show has been copied out in ''Groans of Great Britain'', once credited to [[Daniel Defoe]] but since reattributed to [[Charles Gildon]] (d. 1724), with a description of some of the many extraneously added characters and elements:
"At Punch's Theater in the Little Piazza, Covent-Garden, this present Evening will be performed an Entertainment, called, ''The History of Sir Richard Whittington'', shewing his Rise from a Scullion to be Lord-Mayor of London, with the Comical Humours of Old Madge, the jolly Chamber-maid, and the Representation of the Sea, and the Court of Great Britain, concluding with the Court of Aldermen, and ''Whittington Lord-Mayor'', honoured with the Presence of [[Henry VIII|K. Hen. VIII.]] and his Queen [[Anne Boleyn|Anna Bullen]], with other diverting Decorations proper to the Play, beginning at 6 o' clock".''Groans of Great Britain'', published 1813, at the time considered the work of "[[Daniel Defoe|De Foe]]", quoted in Morley's footnote, p. 53n, in: Addison, ''Spectator'' No. 31, Friday, April 5, 1711; In [[#morley-spectator|Morley's annoted new edition]], pp. 51–53
The puppet play ''Whittington and his Cat'' was reviewed by an anonymous correspondent in ''The Spectator'', No. 14, dated 16 March 1711, soon after it opened.{{Refn|group="lower-alpha" |Morley, in the added notes to ''Spectator'', No. 14 states: "Powell,... who, taking up Addison's joke against the opera from No.5 of the ''Spectator'' (March 6, 1711), produced ''Whittington and his Cat'' as a rival to ''[[Rinaldo (opera)|Rinaldo and Armida]]''". If so, the review in No. 14 of the journal, dated 16 March is less than a fortnight later.}} It featured [[Pulcinella|Punch]] (of the [[Punch and Judy]] shows) as did all of Powell's puppet plays. Punch danced a [[minuet]] with a trained pig in the opening scene. Punch also gave his "reflections on the French" that was a breach of "the Moral", as was King Harry ([[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]) resting his leg on his queen in an immodest manner. Little else on the performance can be gleaned, except that the hero's role (i.e., Punch's role) was performed in a squeaky high voice, just like the lead of the Italian opera ''[[Rinaldo (opera)|Rinaldo and Armida]]'', the rival draw at the time at [[Covent Garden]] which the anonymous reviewer was simultaneously critiquing. The reviewer concludes "as the Wit of both pieces are equal, I must prefer...Mr Powell, because it is in our own language". ===Opera=== An opera production that never came into realization was a topic in [[Joseph Addison]]'s piece in ''[[The Spectator (1711)|The Spectator]]'' (1711). Addison states he was "credibly informed that there was once a Design of casting into an Opera the Story of ''Whittington'' and his Cat, and that in order to it, there had been got together a great Quantity of Mice," but that Mr. Rich ([[Christopher Rich (theatre manager)|Christopher Rich]]) who was proprietor of the playhouse (he managed several including [[Drury Lane theatre]]Rich at one time also managed [[Haymarket Theatre]], which was where [[sparrows]] were released for the opera ''[[Rinaldo (opera)|Rinaldo and Armida]]'', which prompted Addison to write about the release of mice for the possible production of Whittington's tale.) objected that the rodents once released will not be thoroughly collected.Addison, ''The Spectator'' No. 5, Tuesday, 6 March 1711; In [[#morley-spectator|Morley's annoted new edition]], p. 13Quoted in {{Harvp|Wheatley|1885|pp=xvii–xviii}}{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|It is not so clear if Addison wrote the mice idea in earnest or in jest, but stage critic [[Dutton Cook]] (1878) in an article on "Stage Properties" repeats this story at face value.{{citation|last=Cook |first=Dutton |author-link=Edward Dutton Cook |title=Stage Properties |journal=Belgravia |volume=35 |number=139 |year=1878 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oViARV9w59wC&pg=PA288 |pages=288–289}} The use of sparrows is given as fact.[[Allardyce Nicoll|Nicoll, Allardyce]] (1925) ''A History of Early Eighteenth Century Drama'', p. 30 "verisimilitude down to sparrows and tomtits"}} Later ''Whittington and his Cat'', an opera written by Samuel Davey, was performed at the [[Smock Alley Theatre|Theatre in Smock Alley]], Dublin, 1739.Baker et al. (1812), ''{{plain link|name=Names of dramas: M-Z|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rpAUAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA402}}', p. 402, citing Hitchcock, Robert (1788), ''{{Plain link|name=An Historial View of the Irish Stage, '''I'''|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HqU_AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA104}}'', p. 104 regarding authorship. ''[[Whittington (opera)|Whittington]]'', with music by [[Jacques Offenbach]] and English text by [[H. B. Farnie]] was first produced at the [[Alhambra Theatre]] over Christmas 1874–75,[[Kurt Gänzl|Gänzl, Kurt]]. [http://www.operetta-research-center.org/main.php?task=5&cat=4&sub_cat=10&id=00044 "Jacques Offenbach"]{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727082145/http://www.operetta-research-center.org/main.php?task=5&cat=4&sub_cat=10&id=00044 |date=27 July 2011 }}, Operetta Research Center, 1 January 2001Elsom, H. E. [http://www.concertonet.com/scripts/review.php?ID_review=2870 "And his cat"], Concertonet.com (2005) and in 1895 the [[comic opera]] ''[[Dandy Dick Whittington]]'' written by [[George Robert Sims]] and composed by [[Ivan Caryll]] played at the [[Avenue Theatre]].Adams, William Davenport. [https://books.google.com/books?id=TzwOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA374 ''A Dictionary of the Drama: a Guide to the Plays, Playwrights''], Vol. 1, Chatto & Windus, 1904, pp. 374–75 ===Pantomime=== The first recorded pantomime version of the story was in 1814, starring [[Joseph Grimaldi]] as Dame Cicely Suet, the Cook.{{cite journal|title=Drama, &c.|journal=The Lady's magazine (and museum of the belles lettres...)|series=Improved series enlarged|volume=VIII|date=January 1836|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_0cFAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA63|pages=63–4}}{{harvp|Pickering|Morley|1993|p=66}}, spelt "Cecily Suet". [[Ella Shields]] (Camden Theatre, 1907), [[Sybil Arundale]] ([[Theatre Royal, Birmingham|Theatre Royal]], Birmingham, 1908), Helen Gilliland ([[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum]], 1925) are among the actresses who have played the [[principal boy]].{{citation|author=anonymous |title=Patomime Day |journal= The Bystander: An Illustrated Weekly, Devoted to Travel, Literature ... |volume=16 |date=25 December 1907 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gdwRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA622 |page=622}}{{citation|last=Moore |first=F. Michael |title=Drag!: Male and Female Impersonators on Stage, Screen and Television: An Illustrated World History |publisher=McFarland & Company Incorporated Pub |year=1994 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mP5kAAAAMAAJ |pages=48–49|isbn=978-0-8995-0996-9}} Cast in other productions are listed below. Dick's cat has been given the names Thomas, Tommy, Tommy Tittlemouse (1890),{{cite journal|title=24th Crystal Palace Whittington an His Cat |journal=Dramatic Notes |volume=12 |date=December 1890 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MtIUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA166 |page=166}} or Mouser (1908).{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|Drury Lane 1908, listed below. Photographs of the show, including [[George Ali]] as cat occurs in ''The Sketch'', 27 January 1909.{{cite journal|title=The Drama of To-day |journal=The Sketch |volume=61 |date=27 January 1909 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=34A4AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA106 |page=106}}}}{{cite journal|title=The Drama of To-day |journal=The Englishman |volume=1 |number=11 |date=6 January 1909 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8w9OAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA258 |page=258}} and so forth. The pantomime has introduced an arch villain, the Pantomime King Rat (or King of Rats),{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|King Rat has been played by [[Andrew Sachs]]{{sfnp|Pickering|Morley|1993|pp=xvii–xviii}}, and Queen Rat by [[Honor Blackman]]{{sfnp|Pickering|Morley|1993|p=xviii}} and other actresses.}} as well as the usual pantomime fairy, the Fairy of the Bells, personifying the London bells.{{sfnp|Pickering|Morley|1993|p=67}} An early record of King Rat and fairy occurs in an 1877 production at [[Surrey Theatre]]. This production pitches the archvillain King Rat against the [[Fairy Queen]], for whom the fairy [[Beau Bell (disambiguation)|Beau Bell]] serves as messenger.{{cite journal|last=anonymous |title=Christmas Entertainments: Surrey |journal=The Illustrated London News |volume=71 |date=29 December 1877|page=619}}; "Christmas Pantomimes", 22 December 1877, [https://books.google.com/books?id=wZtQAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA591 p. 591] "King Rataplan (Rat-a-plan)" occurs even earlier, alongside "Queen Olivebranch" who assigns [[Cupid]] to uplift Dick Whittington from poverty, in a [[Charles Millward]] script for the Theatre Royal, Birmingham production of 1870.{{citation|last=Millward |first=Charles |title=The Grand Comic Christmas Pantomime entitled Dick Whittington and his Cat |date=26 December 1870 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e85ZAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA17 }} In some versions, Dick and his cat Tommy travel to Morocco, where the cat rids the country of rats. The Sultan rewards Dick with half of his wealth.{{cite web|last=Ellacott |first=Nigel |last2=Robbins |first2=Peter (d. 2009) |url=http://www.its-behind-you.com/dickwhittington.html |title=Dick Whittington |work=Its-behind-you |year=2007}} The pantomime version remains popular today. Other notable pantomime productions included an 1877 version at the [[Surrey Theatre]] described below, as well as the following: * 1872 on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], with music by William H. Brinkworth.[http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=444798 ''Dick Whittington and His Cat''], IBDB database. Retrieved 18 December 2012 * 1877 at the Surrey Theatre in London, entitled ''Dick Whittington and His Cat; Or, Harlequin Beau Bell, Gog and Magog, and the Rats of Rat Castle'', by Frank Green, with music by Sidney Davis, opening 24 December 1877. With comedian [[Arthur Williams (actor)|Arthur Williams]], Topsy Venn was Dick, and David Abrahams{{Efn|or "Master Forrest", first name not given.}} as the cat. The [[Harlequinade]] also featured Tom Lovell as Clown."(Review) Whittington and his Cat at the Surrey", ''The Era'', 27 January 1878, p. 7b, posted in Culme, John, [http://footlightnotes.tripod.com/20081220home.html Footlight Notes ], no. 587, 13 December 2008 *1891 by Geoffrey Thorne, with music by William H. Brinkworth at the Grand Theatre, with [[Lottie Collins]].{{cite journal|title=Grand Theatre—Whittington an His Cat |journal=Dramatic Notes |volume=13 |date=December 1891 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MtIUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA240 |pages=240–241}} *1894 at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], with a libretto by [[Cecil Raleigh]] and [[Henry Hamilton (playwright)|Henry Hamilton]]. The cast included [[Ada Blanche]] as Dick, [[Dan Leno]] as Jack the idle apprentice, [[Herbert Campbell]] as Eliza the cook and Marie Montrose as Alice.''The Times'', 27 December 1894, p. 3 *1908 at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], with a libretto by J. Hickory Wood and Arthur Collins and music composed and arranged by Arthur Collins. The cast included [[Queenie Leighton]] as Dick, [[Wilkie Bard]] as Jack Idle, Marie Wilson as Alice and [[George Ali]] as Mouser, the cat.''The Times'', 28 December 1908, p. 6 *1909, starring [[Tom Foy]], [[Lupino Lane]] and [[Eric Campbell (actor)|Eric Campbell]] at the Shakespeare Theatre, [[Liverpool]]. *1910 at the King's Theatre [[Hammersmith]], with a libretto by Leslie Morton. The cast included Kathleen Gray as Dick, Adela Crispin as Alice, Jack Hurst as the cat, Percy Cahill as Jack, [[Robb Wilton]] as Alderman Fitzwarren and [[Wee Georgie Wood]] as Alice's brother.''The Times'', 27 December 1910, p. 7 *1923 at the [[London Palladium]]. The cast included [[Clarice Mayne]] as Dick, Hilda Glyder as Alice, Fred Whittaker as the cat, and Nellie Wallace and Harry Weldon as the villains.''The Times'', 27 December 1923, p. 5 *1931 at the [[Garrick Theatre]]. The cast included [[Dorothy Dickson]] as Dick, Jean Adrienne as Alice, Roy Barbour as Alderman Fitzwarren, Hal Bryan as Idle Jack, Harry Gilmore as the cat and Jack Morrison as Susan the cook.''The Times'', 28 December 1931, p. 6 *1932 at the [[London Hippodrome]]. The cast included [[Fay Compton]] as Dick, Audrey Pointing as Alice, Fred Wynne as Alderman Fitzwarren, Johnny Fuller as the cat, [[Leslie Henson]] as Idle Jack.''The Times'', 27 December 1932, p. 6 *1935 at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]]. ===Other adaptations=== Dramatic play versions were written by [[H. J. Byron]] in 1861,{{citation|last=Byron |first=Henry James |last2=Davis |first2=Jim |title=Plays by H. J. Byron: The Babes in the Wood, The Lancashire Lass, Our Boys, The Gaiety Gulliver |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1984 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o7g8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA216 |pages=216 |isbn=978-0-5212-8495-0}} [[Robert Reece]] in 1871. A number of television versions have been created, including a [[ITV Panto|2002 version]] written by [[Simon Nye]] and directed by [[Geoff Posner]].[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0305430/ 2002 television version at IMDB database] ==Relics== There are various pieces of art and architecture which have been used to try to date the Whittington association to earlier than the 1600s. The [[Renold Elstracke|Elstracke]] engraving providing Whittington's portrait with a cat had been ascribed a c. 1590 date by some 19th century authors. A Newgate statue claiming to be Whittington's cat was actually a Libertas goddess statue, and though there were suggestions it was made by the executors of Whittington's will when they rebuilt the prison, the existence of the statues prior to the Great Fire of 1666 cannot be firmly established. Other relics are a relief tablet of a boy and animal said to be found at a home that belonged to the family, a chariot with a cat carving that was the gift of the family. ===Early painting with cat=== A Whittington portrait painting depicting the mayor with a cat, allegedly dating to 1532, was once kept at the [[Mercers' Hall]].{{sfnp|Lysons|1860|p=42}}{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|pp=}} The original has been lost, prompting [[Henry B. Wheatley|Wheatley]] to remark that the disappeared artwork "can scarcely be put in evidence".{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|p=viii}} However, a facsimile of it has been reproduced in engraving in ''The New Wonderful Museum'' (1805) edited by William Granger and James Caulfield (see image at top).{{sfnp|Granger|Caulfield|1805|p=1419}} The portrait painting that did exist at [[Mercers' Hall]], affixed with a 1536 date had been witnessed and described by [[James Peller Malcolm]] (d. 1815) in ''Londinium Redivivum'', Vol. 4 (1807). The painting was in the apartment of the clerk of [[Worshipful Company of Mercers|Mercers' Company]] at Mercers' Hall. According to Malcolm, this portrait of Whittington's had "on the left hand.. a black and white cat, whose right ear reaches up to the band or broad turning down to the shirt of the figure". Malcolm admits that the 1536 date had been repainted at a later date after the canvas was cropped, but commented that "it is hardly to be supposed" that this date "was then invented".{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Malcolm |first=James Peller |title=Londinium Redivivum |publisher=Nichols and Son |year=1807 |url=https://books.google.com/books?&id=Sck_AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA515 |pages=515–516}} This painting had disappeared by the time [[Samuel Lysons (priest)|Rev. Samuel Lysons]], who published the mayor's biography in 1860, requested a viewing of it Mercer's Hall. Another portrait was available for him to see, but it was more modern and did not correspond to Malcolm's descriptions. At Mercer's hall also had on display an engraved portrait of Whittington and his cat by [[Guillaume Philippe Benoist]].{{sfnp|Lysons|1860|p=42}} The Benoist was published 1766, and according to the caption represents the Whittington and cat portrait then still hanging at Mercer's Hall.{{Efn|"Sr. Richd. Wittington, from an Original Painting at Mercers Hall". The caption and the illustration are virtually the same as the [[:File:Richard Wittington and his Cat.jpg image]] reproduced in ''The New Wonderful Museum'' (1805),{{sfnp|Granger|Caulfield|1805|p=1419}} shown above. One difference is the signature "Benoist sculp" legible on bottom right rim of the 1766 print.}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portraitLarge/mw147550/Fictitious-portrait-of-Richard-Dick-Whittington |title=Fictitious portrait of Richard ('Dick') Whittington |work=National Portrait Gallery |year=2017|accessdate=20 December 2017}} (Shelfmark D33978){{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|The Benoist was used in [[William Thornton]]'s ''The New, Complete, and Universal History, Description, and Survey of the cities of London and Westminster'' (1784),{{sfnp|Lysons|1860|p=42}} as well as in Lambert's ''History and Survey of London'' (1805).{{cite web|url=http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?assetId=1188344001&objectId=3461564&partId=1 |title=Sr Richd Whittington |work=British Museum |accessdate=20 December 2017}} (Shelfmark 1927,1126.1.30.64, from Lambert's 1805 book)}} ===Early engraving with cat=== There was also an early engraving by [[Renold Elstracke|Reginald Elstrack]] (1570 – after 1625). This engraving, entitled the "True Portraicture" or ''Vera Effigies Preclarmi Domini Richardi Whittington Equi Aurat'' is reproduced in the inset of Lyson's work.{{Harvp|Lysons|1860|pp=15–18, 43–46}} The engraving cannot be definitely dated; Lysons noted that the printmaker flourished c. 1590, and this is the date assigned by [[Walter Besant|Sir Walter Besant]] and [[James Rice (writer)|James Rice]],{{Harvp|Besant|Rice|1881|p=132}} but other sources give a 1605 date.{{cite book|last=Globe |first=Alexander V. |title=Whittington, Sir Richard |work=Peter Stent, London Printseller |place=Vancouver |publisher=University of British Columbia Press |year=2011 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gXwK5LH8v0EC&pg=PA87 |page=87}} On the prints can be read "R. Elstrack ''Sculpsit''" at bottom,{{cite web|url=http://www.fitzmuseum.cam.ac.uk/support/artfund/opac/cataloguedetail.html?&priref=34813&_function_=xslt&_limit_=25 |title=Vera Effigies Preclarmi Domini Richardi Whittington Equi Aurat |work=The Fitzwilliam Museum |publisher=University of Cambridge |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140121034207/http://www.fitzmuseum.cam.ac.uk/support/artfund/opac/cataloguedetail.html?&priref=34813&_function_=xslt&_limit_=25 |archivedate=21 January 2014 |df= }} which is truncated in Lysons's reproduction. It has also been noted that the engraving originally depicted Whittington with a skull under his hand, but had been replaced with a cat underneath, to cater to public taste, "as the common people did not care to buy the print without it".{{citation|last=Granger|first=James|title=A biographical history of England|volume=1|edition=3|year=1779|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KkDdXWZegeQC&pg=PA63|page=63}}Granger vol. I, p. 63 is cited in {{Harvp|Lysons|1860|p=43}}{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|Lysons adduces the Elstrack's print as bearing a close resemblance ("as identical as can possibly be") to a contemporary source (an illumination on an ordinance).{{sfnp|Lysons|1860|p=44}} But this is a deathbead drawing of the mayor which does not help corroborate the cat legend. A facsimile of the deathbed drawing is given in Lysons' book.{{harvp|Lysons|1860}}, {{plain link|url=https://books.google.com/books/content?id=vA8HAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA68-IA3|name=p. 68, opposite}}.}} ===Newgate statue=== The antiquarian [[Thomas Pennant]] believed that a statue of Whittington with his cat was installed in a [[Niche (architecture)|niche]] in [[Newgate]]) in 1412, by the executors of Whittington's estate, but that it was damaged in [[The Great Fire of 1666]] and replaced.{{cite book|last=Pennant Thomas |first=|author-link=Thomas Pennant |title=(Some) Account of London |edition=34 |publisher=John Archer |year=1791|origyear=1790|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LRJbAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA232 |page=223}}{{harvp|Lysons|1860|p=47}}, citing Pennant. [[Samuel Lysons|Lysons]]{{sfnp|Lysons|1860|p=47}} and others{{sfnp|Besant|Rice|1881|p=136}} had lent some credance to this statement by Pennant. But much of Pennant's assumptions here have been subjected to corrections and refutations. This "assertion that a carved figure of a cat existed on Newgate gaol before the great fire is an unsupported assumption," or so it was pronounced by historian [[Charles Lethbridge Kingsford]].{{EB1911|noprescript=1|volume=28|wstitle=Whittington, Richard|page=615}} Work on Newgate at Whittington's bequest did not commence during his lifetime in 1412, but in 1442.Way, R. E., correspondence, in ''{{plain link|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8LosAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA266|name=The Antiquary}}'' '''III''', p. 266, 31 May 1873 (in reply to T. R., p. 200). A copy of Whittington's will kept at Guildhall that prescribes this fails to mention a statue, or him and his cat.{{Refn|Latin text and translation of this brief will is given by Price's article in ''Transactions of the London and Middlesex Archaeological Society'', 5}} This statue was actually the female [[Liberty (goddess)|Liberty]] ("Libertas" carved on the hat) with a cat at her feet, but it was "alluding to" Richard Whittington, as explained by Maitland.{{cite book|last=Maitland|first=William|title=The history and survey of London: from its foundation to the present time|publisher=T. Osborne and J. Shipton|volume=2|year=1756|page=950|url=https://archive.org/stream/historysurveyofl02mait#page/950/mode/2up}}{{harvp|Lysons|1860|p=47}}, citing Maitland. The stone Liberty was one of a set of seven, the others being Peace, Plenty, Concord, and Justice, Mercy, and Truth. This Whittington statue (Liberty statue) was taken down when the old [[Newgate]] was being demolished, in 1766 or 1776, to be placed in the new [[Newgate Prison]].Year given as 1776 and quote from "diurnal" entry (Tuesday, 9 July, [1776]) in: {{citation|last=Burn|first=Jacob Henry|title=A Descriptive Catalogue|year=1855|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vEMGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA177|page=177}}{{Refn|Year given as 1766, and paraphrase of "journal" in Price's article.}}{{cite journal|last=Price |first=John Edward |title=On Recent Discoveries in Newgate Street |journal=Transactions of the London and Middlesex Archaeological Society |volume=5 |year=1881 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9mxIAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA416 |pages=416–419}}{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|Which contradicts Pennant's belief that the statue was demolished when the new [[Newgate prison]] was built.}} The Liberty statue could later be seen at the new Newgate Prison, but the cat was not with her. ===Chariot with carved cat=== Also a chariot with a carved cat, purportedly presented by Whittington's heirs to the merchant's guild in 1572, was available for the biographer [[Samuel Lysons]] to examine.{{sfnp|Lysons|1860|p=47}} ===Boy and a cat from Gloucester=== It was purported that in 1862 at the site of a former residence of Whittington (in [[Gloucester]]), there was unearthed a piece of stone, possibly chimney stone, bearing a ''[[bas-relief|basso relievo]]'' of a boy holding a cat. It was allegedly of 15th-century workmanship. The relic came into the possession of [[Samuel Lysons]].{{citation|last=Lysons|first=Samuel |author-link=Samuel Lysons (priest) |title=Whittington and His Cat: |journal=Notes and Queries |series=3 |volume=II |date=16 August 1862 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gdo1AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA121 |pages=121–122}}Overall, W. H., correspondence, in ''{{plain link|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8LosAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA266|name=The Antiquary}}'' '''III''', p. 266, 31 May 1873 (in reply to T. R., p. 200). Besant and Rice called this "remarkable proof" that the cat story was in the family,{{sfnp|Besant|Rice|1881|p=137}} but Wheatley thought "this find, however, appears rather suspicious".{{sfnp|Wheatley|1885|p=vi}} This artwork could have been acquired after the cat legend was established, as American folklorist [[Jennifer Westwood]] points out,{{Efn|"The story is sometimes connected, whether as cause or effect, with a limestone bas-relief found in a house in Gloucester in 1862", Westwood (1984), p. 114.}} and the supposed "cat" looked more like a lamb to others.{{citation |last=Westwood |first=Jennifer |author-link=Jennifer Westwood |title=Albion: A Guide to Legendary Britain |publisher=HarperCollins Canada, Limited |year=1985 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=quDZAAAAMAAJ |pages=112–114|isbn=978-0-2461-1789-2}} The cat has been preserved at the Gloucester Folk Museum (now called [[Gloucester Life]] Museum), but taken off display.{{sfnp|Westwood|1985|p=114}} ==Notes== ===Explanatory notes=== {{notelist}} ===Citations=== {{reflist}} ==References== * Addison and Steele, edd. (1711), {{plain link|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/12030|name=''The Spectator, Volumes 1, 2 and 3 by Joseph Addison and Sir Richard Steele''}} at [[Project Gutenberg]] **{{cite journal|ref=morley-spectator|editor-last1=Addison |editor-first1=Joseph |editor-link=Joseph Addison| editor-last2=Steele |editor-first2=Richard |editor-link2=Richard Steele |others=Morley, Henry (notes) |title=No.5 (March 6, 1711), No.14 (March 16, 1711), No. 31 (April 5, 1711) |journal=The Spectator |edition=New |place=London, Glasgow, New York |publisher=George Routledge and Sons |year=1888 |origyear=1711 |url=https://archive.org/stream/spectatornewedre00addiuoft#page/24/mode/2up |pages=13, 24–26, 51–53}} *{{cite book|ref=harv|last1=Besant |first1=Sir Walter |last2=Rice |first2=James |title=Sir Richard Whittington Lord Mayor of London |publisher=M. Ward |year=1881 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D24BAAAAQAAJ}} *{{citation|last=Chappell |first=William |title=The Roxburghe Ballads |volume=Part XX, Vol. VII |publisher=for the Ballad Society |year=1895 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=49YUAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA578 |pages=578–586}} *{{citation|last1=Chappell |first1=William |last2=Macfarren |first2=G. A. (George Alexander), Sir |title=Popular Music of the Olden Time |volume=2 |publisher= Cramer, Beale & Chappell |year=1859 |url=https://archive.org/stream/popularmusicofol02chapuoft#page/516/mode/2up |pages=515–517}} *{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Jacobs |first=Joseph |chapter=Whittington and his Cat |title=English Fairy Tales |publisher=Longman |year=1890 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IZvGIR27HLcC&pg=PA167 |pages=167–178, 248 (notes)}} *{{cite book|ref={{SfnRef|Johnson|1612}}|last=Johnson |first=Richard |title=The Crown Garland of Golden Roses |year=1842 |origyear=1612 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-6ciAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA20 |pages=20–25}} *{{citation|last=Lysons|first=Samuel |author-link=Samuel Lysons (priest) |title=The Model Merchant of the Middle Ages: Exemplified in the Story of Whittington and His Cat:|publisher=Hamilton, Adams and Company |year=1860 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zZkiFXpZyUgC&pg=PA42|page=42}} *{{cite book|ref=harv|last1=Pickering |first1=David |author-link1=David Pickering (writer) |last2=Morley |first2=John |title=Dick Whittington |work=Encyclopedia of Pantomime |publisher=Gale Research International |year=1993 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MlhWAAAAMAAJ |pages=65–67}} *{{cite book|ref=harv|editor-last=Wheatley|editor-first=Henry Benjamin|title=The History of Sir Richard Whittington, by T. H. |series=Chap-books and Folk-lore Tracts|publisher=for the Villon Society|year=1885|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1QXXAAAAMAAJ}} ==External links== *[http://storynory.com/2007/02/25/dick-whittington-cat-london/ Background and links, including to an audio version of the story] *[http://www.mainlesson.com/display.php?author=steel&book=english&story=dick The legend] from ''English Fairy Tales'', by Flora Annie Steel *[http://www.its-behind-you.com/shakespeareliv.html Detailed description of a 1909 version of the pantomime] *[http://www.xmission.com/~emailbox/whittington.htm Another version of the legend] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146624/ 1936 animated version at IMDB database] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0406708/ 1937 television version at IMDB database] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0396794/ 1956 television version at IMDB database] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0699603/ 1958 television version at IMDB database] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1062261/ 1972 television version at IMDB database] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0305430/ 2002 television version at IMDB database] {{italic title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dick Whittington And His Cat}} [[Category:English fairy tales]] [[Category:English heroic legends]] [[Category:Pantomime]] [[Category:17th-century broadside ballads]] [[Category:English folklore]] [[Category:Medieval legends]] [[Category:Cats in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Fictional cats]]

{{Multiple issues| {{orphan|date=November 2010}} {{cleanup|date=December 2010}} }}
{{italic title}} '''''Early and Medieval Chinese History'''''（''EMCH''《早期中國史研究》） is an academic periodical magazine, about [[History of China#Ancient China|Ancient]] and [[Medieval China|Medieval Chinese]] history studies, published by the [[Society of Early and Medieval Chinese History]] ([[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]]).
==History== In 2009, some members of the Studies Group of Medieval Chinese History at [[National Taiwan University]] (NTU), [[Li-hsin Chao]] [[National Chi Nan University]] as the promoter of this group, starting to emerge a new academic community. The ''EMCH'' is one of their main and routine acativites.
Members of the Society of EMCH including young scholars from Taiwan, Mainland China, Japan, Canada, i.e. [[Huaichen Kan]] (the chairman at the Dept. of History, NTU, Taipei), [[Yukinobu Abe]] (professor, Fine Liberal Art College, [[Chuuoun University]], Tokyo), [[Albert Dien]] (emeritus professor, [[Stanford University]], U.S.), [[Joshui Chen]] (Dean at the College of Fine Liberal Art, NTU, Taipei), [[Guangda Zhang]] (Academician, [[Academia Sinica]], Taipei) etc. Official website is designed and run by Chung-cheng Tu (National Cheng-kung University).
For now on, there are five volumes published or publishing, papers of each volume including thesis, research note, discussion, book review, and latest information about academic acativities in Taiwan, China, and Japan.
The editors in chief have played important role in EMCH, by volume, they are Zongxian Tsai (2009, National Chung Hsing University, Taiwan), Yun-jo Lin (2010, Tunghai University, Taiwan), Li-hsin Chao (2011, National Chi Nan University, Taiwan), Zhaoyi Lee (2012, Chaoyang University of Technology, Taiwan), An-tai Wang (2013, National Taiwan University), Wan-jun Wang (2014, Soochow University), Chung-cheng Tu (2015, National Chengong University), and Ya-ju Cheng (2016, IHP, Academia Sinica).
Contents of the latest issue (Vol. 8, No.1; June 2016) of EMCH is as below.
〔Article〕 The “Chu People” from the Late Warring States Period to the Early Western Han Dynasty Xiqi Lu
The Yan-household Inscribed in the Stele of King Gwanggaeto: A Discussion of Tomb Keeper System in Ancient East Asia Huai-Chen Kan
〔Research Notes〕 A Study of the Series of Official Posts Called “Protector” （duhu 督護） and the Liang’s of Anding （安定梁氏） in the Former Liang: with a Focus on the “Liang Shu Grave Inscription” Yan Xia
A Textual Study of the Epitaph of Zhangsun Xin Chong Xu
〔Academic News〕 An Overview of British Studies in Early and Medieval Chinese History, 1996-2016 Peiying Lin, Yang Fu
Report from a Forum on the Interaction between Historical Research and Historical Drama, Historical Fiction and Public History Yun-wei Hu
==ISSN== {{ISSN|2075-0366}}
==References== *〈發刊辭〉，趙立新、蔡宗憲，《早期中國史研究》第1卷（2009.7）。 *[http://readopac2.ncl.edu.tw/nclJournal/search/guide/detail.jsp?mark=basic&dtdId=000075&sysId=0006564185&la=ch National Central Library, Taipei, Taiwan 臺灣期刊論文索引系統：《早期中國史研究》，2009-12-22]。 *[http://homepage.ntu.edu.tw/~history/public_html/09info/other.html 「早期中國史研究會成立」．Academic News, Dep. of History, National Taiwan University 臺灣大學歷史學系．學界學術消息，2009-11-5]。 *[http://www.wangf.net/vbb2/showthread.php?threadid=25283 「台湾《早期中国史研究》创刊」，往复论坛，2009-11-17]。 *[http://sekio516.exblog.jp/14867725/ 『早期中国史研究』，關尾史郎のブログ:2011年05月]。 *[http://iwamoto.asablo.jp/blog/2009/12/02/4735930 「拝受 早期中国史研究 第1巻」，Marginal Notes & Marginalia，2009年12月2日]。
==Link== *[http://emchistory.blogspot.com/ EMCH: The society of Early and Medieval Chinese History] *[https://zh-tw.facebook.com/EMCH%E6%97%A9%E6%9C%9F%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B%E5%8F%B2%E7%A0%94%E7%A9%B6-460591194078476/info?tab=page_info EMCH早期中國史研究會]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Early and Medieval Chinese History}} [[Category:Publications established in 2009]] [[Category:History journals]] [[Category:Historiography of China]]
